_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
¿ California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
¿ Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
¿ California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
¿ Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as
necessary. To accomplish this, Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist
us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities.

1.1 PARAMOUNT CITRUS - DELANO (D1) FACILITY, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been
prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities:

Process Name          Process Chemical           Process Quantity(lbs.)
NER - Storage         Ammonia                     14,000
SER - Degreening      Ammonia                      5,900

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of
hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.

Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite pr

oud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker
and public safety. We have:
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.

1.2 PROCESS DESCRIPTIONS

Paramount Citrus D1 operates a commercial packing and storage facility for oranges in Delano, CA. The facility has two ammonia systems (Degreening and Cold Storage). The Degreening
System provides refrigeration capacity to one (1) plate and frame heat exchanger that is used to chill glycol. The Cold Storage System provides refrigeration capacity to three (3) cold storage
rooms and one (1) loading dock. The cold storage rooms and loading dock both utilize ceiling suspended evaporator coils that contain chilled liquid ammonia. A computer system provides
substantial control and alarm capability.

Both the Degreening and Cold Storage Systems are pumped overfeed systems and operate as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a series of liquid feed
solenoid valves, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator. From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve
and into evaporator. Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator. Low pressure and temperature gas and overfeed liquid passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the
liquid recirculator. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the suction gas is piped to screw compressor

s which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The
high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquified and returned to a thermosyphon vessel, and
from the thermosyphon vessel it returns to the high pressure receiver. High pressure liquid from the thermosyphon vessel is supplied to the oil coolers on each screw compressor. High
temperature liquid is evaporated in the oil cooler and a combination of high temperature gas and liquid is returned to the thermosyphon vessel by thermosyphon action.

The Paramount Citrus D1 facility was originally built in the 1998 by California Controlled Atmosphere and has been added to since that time. Most recently the following projects have occurred:
2012/2013 - American Incorporated renovated the computer control system (Cold Storage System and Degreening System)
2012 - American Incorporated installed new evaporative condensers on both systems.
2012 - American Incorporated installed a new high pressure receiver, screw compressor, cold box, and loading dock (Cold Storage System)

The facility was designed and installed by professional refrigeration engineers in accordance with industry standards at the time. It was also built in compliance with the Uniform Mechanical Code
and Uniform Building Code applicable at the time of construction. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures
exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. Lastly, each system has an
emergency dump box that contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.

The ammonia systems at Paramount Citrus D1 consist of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate ve

riter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain
help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of Resource Compliance's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.

For the future, Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Paramount Citrus -
Delano (D1) Facility employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility will continue to maintain overall
plant worker and public safety.

ssels that
are not directly connected. Therefore, each system is treated as a single process.

1.3 GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

1.3.1 GENERAL

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss
preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for
the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program.

1.3.2 ANHYDROUS AMMONIA

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this
process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked
frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.

1.4 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 EMERGENCY ACTION AND RESPONSE PLAN

Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
¿ California Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
¿ Federal Emergency Action Plan - Title 29

CFR §1910.38
¿ California Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 §5192(q)
¿ Federal Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR §1910.120(q)

Strategically, we will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the
Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team.

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Our company has an outstanding safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Many policies and procedures have been implemented to promote overall plant, worker and public safety.
Nevertheless, Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility's ability to
communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility's management team
can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Paramount Citrus - Delano (D1) Facility has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection,
process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action
item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMW
